lines.text:
[to the Countess]
Can't we be lonesome together, little peasant maid?

[Alarmed, to his wife as he sees a drunken Sergei]
The Revolution is on the stairs!

[to Sergei]
Come here! Come here, you idiot! I refuse to call an idiot like you twice!
Now I am the master here! Now... I am as good as any man! Kiss me... like you kissed that Captain!
Go downstairs where you belong!

[to her husband]
Try to be a man - at least before your servants!

[to Sergei]
Do you think those upstairs pigs ever keep their promises to us downstairs?

[to Sergei]
See... he gets the kisses and you get the whip!

[to the Countess]
I apologize for my lips, Countess - and I apologize for my eyes - but I cannot apologize for my heart.
Can you show me the way to Novokursk?

[In disguise]
I am a peaceful peasant and he is... my husband.
He is not your husband... and your hands are too white for a peasant's.
We are all equal!
You thick-head! Can't you see that we will soon be the equal to those aristocrats upstairs?
Then... I will be good enough for the Countess? Then could I kiss her... like that Captain kisses her?
So it is you with your foul smelling tobacco?
Take this note to that fat rabbit, Gaidaroff!
Are you so weak-kneed that you fear such ruffians?
Don't you understand? It's time for us to be masters now!
Go on back... you old walrus!

[upstairs]
SERGEI!

[downstairs, to Sergei]
Is that old sea lion barking at you again? Isn't she always calling you idiot... idiot... IDIOT!
Has he been loyal?

[Last lines]
You are going to stay with us always, Sergei.
